elements.content: Although supramolecular isomerism in metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) would offer a favorable platform for in-depth exploring their structure–property relationship, the design and synthesis of the isomers are still rather a challenging aspect of crystal engineering. Here, a pair of supramolecular isomers of Co­(II)-based MOFs (FJU-88 and FJU-89) can be directionally fabricated by rational tuning the additives. In spite of the fact that the isomers have the similar Co3 secondary building units and organic linkers, they adopt distinct networks with acs and snw topologies, respectively, which derive from the conformational flexibility of the organic ligands. It is noteworthy that the porous structure of FJU-88 would be collapsed after removal of the solvent from the pores. But FJU-89a shows permanent porosity accompanied with unusual hierarchical micro- and mesopores and superior gas selective adsorption performance. In addition, FJU-89a can efficiently trap C2H2 from C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4 mixture gases through fixed-bed dynamic breakthrough experiments.
elements.clean_text: Although supramolecular isomerism in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) would offer a favorable platform for in-depth exploring their structure-property relationship, the design and synthesis of the isomers are still rather a challenging aspect of crystal engineering. Here, a pair of supramolecular isomers of Co(II)-based MOFs (FJU-88 and FJU-89) can be directionally fabricated by rational tuning the additives. In spite of the fact that the isomers have the similar Co3 secondary building units and organic linkers, they adopt distinct networks with acs and snw topologies, respectively, which derive from the conformational flexibility of the organic ligands. It is noteworthy that the porous structure of FJU-88 would be collapsed after removal of the solvent from the pores. But FJU-89a shows permanent porosity accompanied with unusual hierarchical micro- and mesopores and superior gas selective adsorption performance. In addition, FJU-89a can efficiently trap C2H2 from C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4 mixture gases through fixed-bed dynamic breakthrough experiments.

elements.content: Acetylene (C2H2) is one of the significant fuel gas and essential raw materials in the petrochemical and electronic industries. Nowadays, mainly there are two acetylene preparation processes, one is derived from the thermal cracking of natural gas (>80% CH4) during which the separation of C2H2 from CH4 meets grade A requirement acetylene for organic synthesis, whereas the departure from the distillates produced during steam cracking in petroleum refining will produce a large number of byproducts (including CO2). However, the similarities between C2H2 and CO2 in the perspective of their shapes, molecular dimensions (3.3 × 3.3 × 5.7 and 3.2 × 3.3 × 5.4 Å3 for C2H2 and CO2, respectively), and physical properties (boiling points of 189.3 for C2H2 and 194.7 K for CO2) make it a great challenge for C2H2 separation. Porous material-based adsorptive separation is considered to be a promising future separation technology with more environment friendly and energy efficient when compared with cryogenic distillation or organic solvent extraction. Among all kinds of solid porous materials, metal–organic framework (MOF) materials are considered to be the most promising candidates for such an application.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Acetylene (C2H2) is one of the significant fuel gas and essential raw materials in the petrochemical and electronic industries. Nowadays, mainly there are two acetylene preparation processes, one is derived from the thermal cracking of natural gas (>80% CH4) during which the separation of C2H2 from CH4 meets grade A requirement acetylene for organic synthesis, whereas the departure from the distillates produced during steam cracking in petroleum refining will produce a large number of byproducts (including CO2). However, the similarities between C2H2 and CO2 in the perspective of their shapes, molecular dimensions (3.3 × 3.3 × 5.7 and 3.2 × 3.3 × 5.4 Å3 for C2H2 and CO2, respectively), and physical properties (boiling points of 189.3 for C2H2 and 194.7 K for CO2) make it a great challenge for C2H2 separation. Porous material-based adsorptive separation is considered to be a promising future separation technology with more environment friendly and energy efficient when compared with cryogenic distillation or organic solvent extraction. Among all kinds of solid porous materials, metal-organic framework (MOF) materials are considered to be the most promising candidates for such an application.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) represent an intriguing type of crystalline porous materials that can be readily self-assembled through the coordination of inorganic metal ions/clusters with organic bridging linkers. In recent years, owing to the structural visualization and tunability, high surface areas, and functional pore cages/channels, the bright potential of MOFs as emerging multifunctional materials is highlighted in many research areas, such as gas storage and separation, liquid phase adsorption/separation, chemical sensing, ion conductors, catalysis, and biomedicine. The term of supramolecular isomerism (or framework isomers) in MOFs was first reviewed by Moulton and Zaworotko in 2001, which can be divided into four main categories: structural, conformational, catenane or interpenetration, and optical isomers. The study of supramolecular isomerism is of high demand, which could provide a convenient platform for the effective construction of its structure–property relationship. Conformational isomers of MOFs contain the same building blocks (metal nodes and organic linkers) and identical stoichiometry, but they differ either by the conformation of flexible organic ligands or by the orientation of inorganic metal nodes. Although some external factors (e.g., temperature, solvent, pH value, and concentration) can be responsible for the construction of conformational isomerism, the difficulty in predicting and controlling the crystallization processes makes the design and synthesis of the conformational isomers challenging. To date, it was not observed that the conformation of the ligands as well as the overall topology in a pair of MOF conformational isomers were affected by the additives.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) represent an intriguing type of crystalline porous materials that can be readily self-assembled through the coordination of inorganic metal ions/clusters with organic bridging linkers. In recent years, owing to the structural visualization and tunability, high surface areas, and functional pore cages/channels, the bright potential of MOFs as emerging multifunctional materials is highlighted in many research areas, such as gas storage and separation, liquid phase adsorption/separation, chemical sensing, ion conductors, catalysis, and biomedicine. The term of supramolecular isomerism (or framework isomers) in MOFs was first reviewed by Moulton and Zaworotko in 2001, which can be divided into four main categories: structural, conformational, catenane or interpenetration, and optical isomers. The study of supramolecular isomerism is of high demand, which could provide a convenient platform for the effective construction of its structure-property relationship. Conformational isomers of MOFs contain the same building blocks (metal nodes and organic linkers) and identical stoichiometry, but they differ either by the conformation of flexible organic ligands or by the orientation of inorganic metal nodes. Although some external factors (e.g., temperature, solvent, pH value, and concentration) can be responsible for the construction of conformational isomerism, the difficulty in predicting and controlling the crystallization processes makes the design and synthesis of the conformational isomers challenging. To date, it was not observed that the conformation of the ligands as well as the overall topology in a pair of MOF conformational isomers were affected by the additives.

elements.content: In the present work, we have successfully obtained a pair of conformational isomers (FJU-88 and FJU-89), by using organic ligand 4-(p-carboxyphenyl)-1,2,4-triazole (HCPT), CoCl2·6H2O and rational tuning the additive agent N,N′,N″-tris­(p-pyridyl)­trimesic amide (TPBTC) (). FJU-88 crystallizes similarly to MIL-88 series (acs topology), but would be collapsed after removal of the solvent from the pores. In contrast, FJU-89 adopts the intriguing snw topological structure, which shows permanent porosity with extraordinary hierarchical pores and superior gas selective adsorption property. Furthermore, FJU-89a can efficiently capture C2H2 from C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4 mixtures through a column breakthrough experiment.
elements.clean_text: In the present work, we have successfully obtained a pair of conformational isomers (FJU-88 and FJU-89), by using organic ligand 4-(p-carboxyphenyl)-1,2,4-triazole (HCPT), CoCl2⋅6H2O and rational tuning the additive agent N,N',N"-tris(p-pyridyl)trimesic amide (TPBTC) (). FJU-88 crystallizes similarly to MIL-88 series (acs topology), but would be collapsed after removal of the solvent from the pores. In contrast, FJU-89 adopts the intriguing snw topological structure, which shows permanent porosity with extraordinary hierarchical pores and superior gas selective adsorption property. Furthermore, FJU-89a can efficiently capture C2H2 from C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4 mixtures through a column breakthrough experiment.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Representation of the Syntheses of a Pair of Conformational Isomers (FJU-88 and FJU-89)

elements.content: A mixture of HCPT (0.5 mmol, 0.094 g) and CoCl2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.120 g) was dissolved in the mixed solution of N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA)–H2O–HBF4 (21 mL, 10:3:1, v/v/v, DMA = N,N′-dimethylacetamide) and then heated in 120 °C oven for 1 day. After cooling to room temperature, the light orange rod-shaped single crystals were obtained (yield: 65%, based on HCPT). Elemental analysis calculated (found) for [Co3(μ3-OH)­(CPT)3(H2O)3]­Cl2(DMA)5.5(H2O)5 (C49H84.5Co3N14.5Cl2O20.5): C, 40.52 (41.84); H, 5.86 (5.71); N, 13.98 (13.65). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) (KBr, cm–1): 3417 (s), 3133 (s), 2924 (m), 1608 (s), 1541 (s), 1402 (s), 1246 (s), 1180 (w), 1093 (s), 864 (m), 785 (s), 696 (m), 624 (m), 517 (s) cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of [Co3(μ3-OH)(CPT)3(H2O)3]Cl2(DMA)5.5(H2O)5 (FJU-88)

A mixture of HCPT (0.5 mmol, 0.094 g) and CoCl2⋅6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.120 g) was dissolved in the mixed solution of N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA)-H2O-HBF4 (21 mL, 10:3:1, v/v/v, DMA = N,N'-dimethylacetamide) and then heated in 120 °C oven for 1 day. After cooling to room temperature, the light orange rod-shaped single crystals were obtained (yield: 65%, based on HCPT). Elemental analysis calculated (found) for [Co3(μ3-OH)(CPT)3(H2O)3]Cl2(DMA)5.5(H2O)5 (C49H84.5Co3N14.5Cl2O20.5): C, 40.52 (41.84); H, 5.86 (5.71); N, 13.98 (13.65). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) (KBr, cm-1): 3417 (s), 3133 (s), 2924 (m), 1608 (s), 1541 (s), 1402 (s), 1246 (s), 1180 (w), 1093 (s), 864 (m), 785 (s), 696 (m), 624 (m), 517 (s) cm-1.

elements.content: A mixture of HCPT (0.5 mmol, 0.094 g), CoCl2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.12 g,) and TPBTC (0.23 mmol, 0.100 g,) was dissolved in the mixed solution of DMA–H2O–HBF4 (21 mL, 10:3:1, v/v/v) and then heated in 120 °C oven for 1 day. After cooling to room temperature, the orange bulk-shaped single crystals were obtained (yield: 55%, based on HCPT). Elemental analysis calculated (found) for [Co3(μ3-OH)­(CPT)3(H2O)3]­Cl2(DMA)6(H2O)6 (C51H91Co3N15Cl2O22): C, 40.46 (41.48); H, 6.06 (5.81); N, 13.88 (14.56). FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3417 (s), 3097 (s), 2939 (w), 1683 (w), 1606 (s), 1512 (s), 1398 (s), 1333 (m), 1297 (m), 1240 (m), 1089 (m), 1016 (m), 839 (m), 784 (s), 711 (w), 592 (m), 534 (m) cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Co3(μ3-OH)(CPT)3(H2O)3]Cl2(DMA)6(H2O)6 (FJU-89)

A mixture of HCPT (0.5 mmol, 0.094 g), CoCl2⋅6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.12 g,) and TPBTC (0.23 mmol, 0.100 g,) was dissolved in the mixed solution of DMA-H2O-HBF4 (21 mL, 10:3:1, v/v/v) and then heated in 120 °C oven for 1 day. After cooling to room temperature, the orange bulk-shaped single crystals were obtained (yield: 55%, based on HCPT). Elemental analysis calculated (found) for [Co3(μ3-OH)(CPT)3(H2O)3]Cl2(DMA)6(H2O)6 (C51H91Co3N15Cl2O22): C, 40.46 (41.48); H, 6.06 (5.81); N, 13.88 (14.56). FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3417 (s), 3097 (s), 2939 (w), 1683 (w), 1606 (s), 1512 (s), 1398 (s), 1333 (m), 1297 (m), 1240 (m), 1089 (m), 1016 (m), 839 (m), 784 (s), 711 (w), 592 (m), 534 (m) cm-1.

elements.content: In a typical synthesis, light orange rod-shaped crystals of FJU-88 were successfully synthesized by heating an equimolar mixture of HCPT and CoCl2·6H2O at 120 °C for 1 day in the mixed DMA–H2O–HBF4 solution. Similarly, the additional supramolecular isomers FJU-89 with orange bulk-shaped crystals can be synthesized by adding TPBTC during this reaction. Obviously, the additives act as the template molecules and play an important role in controlling the supramolecular isomerism in this case, and the mechanistic details are still under investigation. Combining the results of thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and elemental analysis, a pair of conformational isomers was formulated as [Co3(μ3-OH)­(CPT)3(H2O)2]­Cl2(DMA)5.5(H2O)5 for FJU-88 and [Co3(μ3-OH)­(CPT)3(H2O)2]­Cl2(DMA)6(H2O)6 for FJU-89. The phase purity of the as-synthesized sample (FJU-88 and FJU-89) was confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) technology (Figures S6 and S7).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

In a typical synthesis, light orange rod-shaped crystals of FJU-88 were successfully synthesized by heating an equimolar mixture of HCPT and CoCl2⋅6H2O at 120 °C for 1 day in the mixed DMA-H2O-HBF4 solution. Similarly, the additional supramolecular isomers FJU-89 with orange bulk-shaped crystals can be synthesized by adding TPBTC during this reaction. Obviously, the additives act as the template molecules and play an important role in controlling the supramolecular isomerism in this case, and the mechanistic details are still under investigation. Combining the results of thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and elemental analysis, a pair of conformational isomers was formulated as [Co3(μ3-OH)(CPT)3(H2O)2]Cl2(DMA)5.5(H2O)5 for FJU-88 and [Co3(μ3-OH)(CPT)3(H2O)2]Cl2(DMA)6(H2O)6 for FJU-89. The phase purity of the as-synthesized sample (FJU-88 and FJU-89) was confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) technology (Figures S6 and S7).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses show that FJU-88 and FJU-89 have the analogous secondary building units (SBUs) and metal–ligand connection modes, but crystallize in the hexagonal P63/mmc and tetragonal I41/amd space group, respectively, thus they belong to a pair of supramolecular isomers. The Co­(II) ion is coordinated by four distinct CPT ligands, a μ3-OH– anion, and one terminal H2O molecule, with the octahedral geometry. Three Co­(II) ions around a μ3-OH– group are connected by three triazole and three carboxyl groups from six independent CPT ligands to form a typical tri-prismatic SBUs (a,f). Notably, there are trigonal bipyramidal and twisted octahedral cages in FJU-88 and FJU-89 with their center at the Wyckoff position 4a and 2d, and the dimensions of these two cages are estimated to be around 8 and 12 Å, respectively (c,h). Then, the trinuclear Co­(II) SBUs are connected by the organic linkers (CPT) to form a three-dimensional (3D) cationic open framework. FJU-88 shows a hexagonal one-dimensional (1D) channel along the c axis (d) with an aperture size of approximately 14 Å, whereas FJU-89 displays two types of (hexagonal and quadrilateral) 1D channels along the a axis, and with the pore sizes of ca. 12 and 8 Å, respectively (i). If the trinuclear Co­(II) SBUs are viewed as six connected nodes and CPT as two connected linkers, FJU-88 and FJU-89 adopt the acs and snw topological networks, respectively, but with the equal point (Schläfli) symbol of {49·66} (e,j). It was worth mentioning that the rare snw topology network was first fabricated by one-step strategy. After removing the free solvents, the total accessible volumes of FJU-88 and FJU-89 are estimated to be 72.7 and 76.5%, respectively, as determined by PLATON. The average twist angles between the planes of triazole ring and benzene ring of CPT in FJU-88 and FJU-89 are 1.234 and 30.624, 4.641° (b,g), corresponding to relative conformational energies of 82.71 and 78.86, 82.41 kcal/mol. As the free ligand gives the most favorable value of 33.9°, which indicates that the framework of FJU-88 is of higher tension than FJU-89, whereas FJU-89 is a more stable isomer than FJU-88.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Descriptions

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses show that FJU-88 and FJU-89 have the analogous secondary building units (SBUs) and metal-ligand connection modes, but crystallize in the hexagonal P63/mmc and tetragonal I41/amd space group, respectively, thus they belong to a pair of supramolecular isomers. The Co(II) ion is coordinated by four distinct CPT ligands, a μ3-OH- anion, and one terminal H2O molecule, with the octahedral geometry. Three Co(II) ions around a μ3-OH- group are connected by three triazole and three carboxyl groups from six independent CPT ligands to form a typical tri-prismatic SBUs (a,f). Notably, there are trigonal bipyramidal and twisted octahedral cages in FJU-88 and FJU-89 with their center at the Wyckoff position 4a and 2d, and the dimensions of these two cages are estimated to be around 8 and 12 Å, respectively (c,h). Then, the trinuclear Co(II) SBUs are connected by the organic linkers (CPT) to form a three-dimensional (3D) cationic open framework. FJU-88 shows a hexagonal one-dimensional (1D) channel along the c axis (d) with an aperture size of approximately 14 Å, whereas FJU-89 displays two types of (hexagonal and quadrilateral) 1D channels along the a axis, and with the pore sizes of ca. 12 and 8 Å, respectively (i). If the trinuclear Co(II) SBUs are viewed as six connected nodes and CPT as two connected linkers, FJU-88 and FJU-89 adopt the acs and snw topological networks, respectively, but with the equal point (Schläfli) symbol of {49⋅66} (e,j). It was worth mentioning that the rare snw topology network was first fabricated by one-step strategy. After removing the free solvents, the total accessible volumes of FJU-88 and FJU-89 are estimated to be 72.7 and 76.5%, respectively, as determined by PLATON. The average twist angles between the planes of triazole ring and benzene ring of CPT in FJU-88 and FJU-89 are 1.234 and 30.624, 4.641° (b,g), corresponding to relative conformational energies of 82.71 and 78.86, 82.41 kcal/mol. As the free ligand gives the most favorable value of 33.9°, which indicates that the framework of FJU-88 is of higher tension than FJU-89, whereas FJU-89 is a more stable isomer than FJU-88.

elements.content: Trinuclear Co­(II) unit and organic ligand HCPT in FJU-88 (a) and FJU-89 (f) and viewed as six connected nodes and two connected linkers, respectively. The coordination mode and the twist angle between the plane of triazole ring and benzene ring of the CPT in FJU-88 (b) and FJU-89 (g). The trigonal bipyramidal cage Co15(CPT)6 and the twisted octahedral cage Co18(CPT)8 were observed in FJU-88 (c) and FJU-89 (h). (d) The 3D framework of FJU-88 showing hexagonal 1D channel view along the c axis, (i) the 3D framework of FJU-89 showing two types of 1D channels view along the a axis. Schematic views of the acs and snw topological structures in FJU-88 (e) and FJU-89 (j). Color code: Co, orange or light purple; O, red; N, blue; C, dark gray. Guest molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Trinuclear Co(II) unit and organic ligand HCPT in FJU-88 (a) and FJU-89 (f) and viewed as six connected nodes and two connected linkers, respectively. The coordination mode and the twist angle between the plane of triazole ring and benzene ring of the CPT in FJU-88 (b) and FJU-89 (g). The trigonal bipyramidal cage Co15(CPT)6 and the twisted octahedral cage Co18(CPT)8 were observed in FJU-88 (c) and FJU-89 (h). (d) The 3D framework of FJU-88 showing hexagonal 1D channel view along the c axis, (i) the 3D framework of FJU-89 showing two types of 1D channels view along the a axis. Schematic views of the acs and snw topological structures in FJU-88 (e) and FJU-89 (j). Color code: Co, orange or light purple; O, red; N, blue; C, dark gray. Guest molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content: For permanent porosity establishment, the freshly as-synthesized sample was soaked in anhydrous CH3OH to exchange the guest solvents, and then pumped under high vacuum at 333 K overnight to get guest-free phases FJU-88a and FJU-89a. As shown in Figure S10, the 77 K N2 adsorption of FJU-88a is much less and with no pore volume, which may be caused by the removal of solvent from pores and the collapse of porous structures, as the further PXRD patterns confirm (Figure S6). In contrast, the activated FJU-89a showed two types of combined isotherms: type I, a steep rise in the low-pressure range, and type IV, obvious adsorption–desorption hysteresis in the relative pressure range of 0.5–0.9 (a). Such combined adsorption behavior has also been observed in other hierarchically porous MOFs. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller and Langmuir surface area calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherms are 774 and 1202 m2/g, respectively (Figure S11). The total pore volume obtained from the maximum N2 uptake is 0.68 cm3/g (including 0.32 cm3/g of micropore volume), slightly lower than the theoretical value of 1.16 cm3/g. The difference between theoretical and experimental results is mainly due to the shrinkage of the activated host framework, which was further confirmed by the PXRD patterns (Figure S7). The pore-size distribution (PSD) of FJU-89a was calculated using the no-local density functional theory (NLDFT) model, showing the coexistence of micropores and mesopores as the major pores located in the range of 0.5–1.1 and 8–12 nm, respectively (b).
elements.clean_text:
Pore Textural Properties

For permanent porosity establishment, the freshly as-synthesized sample was soaked in anhydrous CH3OH to exchange the guest solvents, and then pumped under high vacuum at 333 K overnight to get guest-free phases FJU-88a and FJU-89a. As shown in Figure S10, the 77 K N2 adsorption of FJU-88a is much less and with no pore volume, which may be caused by the removal of solvent from pores and the collapse of porous structures, as the further PXRD patterns confirm (Figure S6). In contrast, the activated FJU-89a showed two types of combined isotherms: type I, a steep rise in the low-pressure range, and type IV, obvious adsorption-desorption hysteresis in the relative pressure range of 0.5-0.9 (a). Such combined adsorption behavior has also been observed in other hierarchically porous MOFs. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller and Langmuir surface area calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherms are 774 and 1202 m2/g, respectively (Figure S11). The total pore volume obtained from the maximum N2 uptake is 0.68 cm3/g (including 0.32 cm3/g of micropore volume), slightly lower than the theoretical value of 1.16 cm3/g. The difference between theoretical and experimental results is mainly due to the shrinkage of the activated host framework, which was further confirmed by the PXRD patterns (Figure S7). The pore-size distribution (PSD) of FJU-89a was calculated using the no-local density functional theory (NLDFT) model, showing the coexistence of micropores and mesopores as the major pores located in the range of 0.5-1.1 and 8-12 nm, respectively (b).

elements.content: (a) 77 K N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of FJU-89a. (b) The pore-size distribution (PSD) of FJU-89a from the 273 K CO2 and 77 K N2 isotherms based on the no-local density functional theory (NLDFT) model. (c) 273 K and (d) 296 K C2H2 (violet hexagon), CO2 (red circle), and CH4 (green diamond) adsorption isotherms of FJU-89a.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) 77 K N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of FJU-89a. (b) The pore-size distribution (PSD) of FJU-89a from the 273 K CO2 and 77 K N2 isotherms based on the no-local density functional theory (NLDFT) model. (c) 273 K and (d) 296 K C2H2 (violet hexagon), CO2 (red circle), and CH4 (green diamond) adsorption isotherms of FJU-89a.

elements.content: Establishment of permanent porosity and optimized pore space within the framework of FJU-89a encourages us to study its adsorption and separation performances. At 273 K and 1 bar, the uptake capacities of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 are 123.3, 94.2, and 22.5 cm3/g, respectively (c). Similarly, the uptake value of C2H2 is 101.4 cm3/g, which is higher than the values of CO2 (61.1 cm3/g) and CH4 (14.0 cm3/g), at 296 K and 1 bar (d). Although the uptake capacity of C2H2 in FJU-89a at 296 K is lower than some famous MOFs with high density of open-metal sites, for example, FJI-H8 (224 cm3/g) and HKUST-1 (201 cm3/g), the adsorbed C2H2 is comparable to FJU-22a (114.8 cm3/g) and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (91.8 cm3/g) and much higher than ZJU-196a (83.5 cm3/g), UTSA-300a (68.9 cm3/g), and NKMOF-1-Ni (61.0 cm3/g). The zero surface coverage isosteric heat of adsorptions (Q st) of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 for FJU-89a, derived from the 273 K and 296 K adsorption isotherms and fitted using the virial equation, are 31.0, 27.8, and 18.1 kJ/mol, respectively (Figure S12). Obviously, the interaction between C2H2 and host skeleton is stronger than that of CO2 and CH4.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption

Establishment of permanent porosity and optimized pore space within the framework of FJU-89a encourages us to study its adsorption and separation performances. At 273 K and 1 bar, the uptake capacities of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 are 123.3, 94.2, and 22.5 cm3/g, respectively (c). Similarly, the uptake value of C2H2 is 101.4 cm3/g, which is higher than the values of CO2 (61.1 cm3/g) and CH4 (14.0 cm3/g), at 296 K and 1 bar (d). Although the uptake capacity of C2H2 in FJU-89a at 296 K is lower than some famous MOFs with high density of open-metal sites, for example, FJI-H8 (224 cm3/g) and HKUST-1 (201 cm3/g), the adsorbed C2H2 is comparable to FJU-22a (114.8 cm3/g) and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (91.8 cm3/g) and much higher than ZJU-196a (83.5 cm3/g), UTSA-300a (68.9 cm3/g), and NKMOF-1-Ni (61.0 cm3/g). The zero surface coverage isosteric heat of adsorptions (Q st) of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 for FJU-89a, derived from the 273 K and 296 K adsorption isotherms and fitted using the virial equation, are 31.0, 27.8, and 18.1 kJ/mol, respectively (Figure S12). Obviously, the interaction between C2H2 and host skeleton is stronger than that of CO2 and CH4.

elements.content: The notable differences among CH4, CO2, and C2H2 absorption behaviors indicate that FJU-89a might be a promising candidate for C2H2/CH4 and C2H2/CO2 separation. The well-defined ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) is also used to assess the separation selectivity of binary C2H2/CH4 (50:50%) and C2H2/CO2 (50:50%) mixtures at different pressures. At 296 K, the C2H2/CH4 selectivity range is from 42.6 to 65.9 and slightly lower than that of Cu-TDPAT (82) and FJU-12a (79.7), but significantly higher than that of UTSA-72a (26.5) and ZJU-199 (27.3–33.5), and the C2H2/CO2 selectivity range is from 4.3 to 6.6 and comparable to some famous MOFs, such as TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (10–6) and HKUST-1 (10–5). Similarly, at 273 K, the C2H2/CH4 and C2H2/CO2 selectivity ranges are from 54.5 to 84.2 and 4.0 to 6.6, respectively, which are quite high as well. These endue the FJU-89a unfold C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4 separation proficiency (Figure S18).
elements.clean_text: The notable differences among CH4, CO2, and C2H2 absorption behaviors indicate that FJU-89a might be a promising candidate for C2H2/CH4 and C2H2/CO2 separation. The well-defined ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) is also used to assess the separation selectivity of binary C2H2/CH4 (50:50%) and C2H2/CO2 (50:50%) mixtures at different pressures. At 296 K, the C2H2/CH4 selectivity range is from 42.6 to 65.9 and slightly lower than that of Cu-TDPAT (82) and FJU-12a (79.7), but significantly higher than that of UTSA-72a (26.5) and ZJU-199 (27.3-33.5), and the C2H2/CO2 selectivity range is from 4.3 to 6.6 and comparable to some famous MOFs, such as TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (10-6) and HKUST-1 (10-5). Similarly, at 273 K, the C2H2/CH4 and C2H2/CO2 selectivity ranges are from 54.5 to 84.2 and 4.0 to 6.6, respectively, which are quite high as well. These endue the FJU-89a unfold C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4 separation proficiency (Figure S18).

elements.content: To further investigate the C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4 separation performance of FJU-89 in actual process, we conducted lab-scale fixed-bed breakthrough tests at ambient conditions, in which the mixed gases of C2H2/CO2/He (5:5:90, v/v/v) and C2H2/CH4/He (5:5:90, v/v/v) were flowed over a packed column of activated FJU-89a sample with a total flow of 7 and 12 mL/min, respectively. As shown in a, CO2 was detected after the mixed gas had been flowed into the fixed bed for about 17.2 min, whereas C2H2 was not detected until the breakthrough time up to 57.2 min. Similarly, for C2H2/CH4/He gas mixtures, the breakthrough time of CH4 and C2H2 were 3 and 36 min (b), respectively. Thus, the mixed gases of C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4 through a column packed with FJU-89a adsorbent can be efficiently separated. It is noted that a roll-up behavior was observed for CO2, which may be due to a partial substitution of the adsorbed CO2 on the adsorption sites by the stronger adsorptive C2H2 in the gas mixtures. The dynamic C2H2 adsorption capacities in C2H2/CO2/He and C2H2/CH4/He mixtures based on the breakthrough time were found to be 0.94 and 1.04 mmol/g, respectively, which are close to the IAST-predicted results of 1.0 and 1.04 mmol/g (Figures S16 and S17). From the breakthrough curve, the separation factors, α = (q 1 y 2)/(y 1 q 2), were calculated to be 3.0 and 13.1 for the equimolar mixed gases of C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4. The separation factor of C2H2/CO2 in FJU-89a is lower than that of TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (50), UTSA-74a (20.1), and DICRO-4-Ni-i (13), but higher than the value of 2.0 for HOF-3 and 1.9 for FJU-22a. Moreover, the separation factor (13.1) of C2H2/CH4 in FJU-89a is inferior to ZJNU-59 (26.2), but remarkably higher than the value of 5.2 for s-PMO-2. In the actual industrial applications, the ideal adsorbent should have good stability and recycling performance. We thus performed multiple C2H2/CO2/He and C2H2/CH4/He mixed-gas dynamic breakthrough experiments to evaluate the preservation of the separation property of FJU-89a. As shown in c,d, the recycling experiments showed that the values of capture capacity and separation factor keep steady during three dynamic breakthrough tests, further indicating that FJU-89a is a promising candidate for acetylene-containing mixture purification.
elements.clean_text: To further investigate the C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4 separation performance of FJU-89 in actual process, we conducted lab-scale fixed-bed breakthrough tests at ambient conditions, in which the mixed gases of C2H2/CO2/He (5:5:90, v/v/v) and C2H2/CH4/He (5:5:90, v/v/v) were flowed over a packed column of activated FJU-89a sample with a total flow of 7 and 12 mL/min, respectively. As shown in a, CO2 was detected after the mixed gas had been flowed into the fixed bed for about 17.2 min, whereas C2H2 was not detected until the breakthrough time up to 57.2 min. Similarly, for C2H2/CH4/He gas mixtures, the breakthrough time of CH4 and C2H2 were 3 and 36 min (b), respectively. Thus, the mixed gases of C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4 through a column packed with FJU-89a adsorbent can be efficiently separated. It is noted that a roll-up behavior was observed for CO2, which may be due to a partial substitution of the adsorbed CO2 on the adsorption sites by the stronger adsorptive C2H2 in the gas mixtures. The dynamic C2H2 adsorption capacities in C2H2/CO2/He and C2H2/CH4/He mixtures based on the breakthrough time were found to be 0.94 and 1.04 mmol/g, respectively, which are close to the IAST-predicted results of 1.0 and 1.04 mmol/g (Figures S16 and S17). From the breakthrough curve, the separation factors, α = (q 1 y 2)/(y 1 q 2), were calculated to be 3.0 and 13.1 for the equimolar mixed gases of C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4. The separation factor of C2H2/CO2 in FJU-89a is lower than that of TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (50), UTSA-74a (20.1), and DICRO-4-Ni-i (13), but higher than the value of 2.0 for HOF-3 and 1.9 for FJU-22a. Moreover, the separation factor (13.1) of C2H2/CH4 in FJU-89a is inferior to ZJNU-59 (26.2), but remarkably higher than the value of 5.2 for s-PMO-2. In the actual industrial applications, the ideal adsorbent should have good stability and recycling performance. We thus performed multiple C2H2/CO2/He and C2H2/CH4/He mixed-gas dynamic breakthrough experiments to evaluate the preservation of the separation property of FJU-89a. As shown in c,d, the recycling experiments showed that the values of capture capacity and separation factor keep steady during three dynamic breakthrough tests, further indicating that FJU-89a is a promising candidate for acetylene-containing mixture purification.

elements.content: Dynamic breakthrough curves for (a) C2H2/CO2/He and (b) C2H2/CH4/He gas mixture (5:5:90, v/v/v) in a fixed bed packed with FJU-89a. The values of (c) adsorption capacity and (d) separation factor of FJU-89a in multiple breakthrough experiments.
elements.clean_text: 3  Dynamic breakthrough curves for (a) C2H2/CO2/He and (b) C2H2/CH4/He gas mixture (5:5:90, v/v/v) in a fixed bed packed with FJU-89a. The values of (c) adsorption capacity and (d) separation factor of FJU-89a in multiple breakthrough experiments.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have successfully prepared a pair of MOF conformational isomers by using bifunctional ligand HCPT with transition-metal Co­(II) and rational tuning the additive agents (TPBTC) under solvothermal reactions. It is worth noting that their host skeletons are constructed from the similar Co3 SBUs as well as the same organic linkers, but the resulting topology networks are remarkably different (acs and snw for FJU-88 and FJU-89, respectively), which originate from the conformational flexibility of the organic ligands. The pairs of isomers exhibit notably distinct skeleton robustness upon guest exchange due to their different topology networks. FJU-89a shows permanent porosity accompanied with funny hierarchical micropores and mesopores and superior gas selective adsorption performance. In addition, dynamic breakthrough tests indicate that FJU-89a can efficiently trap C2H2 from C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4 gas mixtures. Our investigation will give a new perspective on the elaborate structure-relationship of MOFs and the rational design of novel hierarchically porous metal–organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have successfully prepared a pair of MOF conformational isomers by using bifunctional ligand HCPT with transition-metal Co(II) and rational tuning the additive agents (TPBTC) under solvothermal reactions. It is worth noting that their host skeletons are constructed from the similar Co3 SBUs as well as the same organic linkers, but the resulting topology networks are remarkably different (acs and snw for FJU-88 and FJU-89, respectively), which originate from the conformational flexibility of the organic ligands. The pairs of isomers exhibit notably distinct skeleton robustness upon guest exchange due to their different topology networks. FJU-89a shows permanent porosity accompanied with funny hierarchical micropores and mesopores and superior gas selective adsorption performance. In addition, dynamic breakthrough tests indicate that FJU-89a can efficiently trap C2H2 from C2H2/CO2 and C2H2/CH4 gas mixtures. Our investigation will give a new perspective on the elaborate structure-relationship of MOFs and the rational design of novel hierarchically porous metal-organic frameworks.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of HCPT (0.5 mmol, 0.094 g) and CoCl2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.120 g) was dissolved in the mixed solution of N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA)–H2O–HBF4 (21 mL, 10:3:1, v/v/v, DMA = N,N′-dimethylacetamide) and then heated in 120 °C oven for 1 day. After cooling to room temperature, the light orange rod-shaped single crystals were obtained (yield: 65%, based on HCPT). Elemental analysis calculated (found) for [Co3(μ3-OH)­(CPT)3(H2O)3]­Cl2(DMA)5.5(H2O)5 (C49H84.5Co3N14.5Cl2O20.5): C, 40.52 (41.84); H, 5.86 (5.71); N, 13.98 (13.65). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) (KBr, cm–1): 3417 (s), 3133 (s), 2924 (m), 1608 (s), 1541 (s), 1402 (s), 1246 (s), 1180 (w), 1093 (s), 864 (m), 785 (s), 696 (m), 624 (m), 517 (s) cm–1.

Synthesis of [Co<sub>3</sub>(μ<sub>3</sub>-OH)­(CPT)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]­Cl<sub>2</sub>(DMA)<sub>6</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub> (<bold>FJU-89</bold>)

A mixture of HCPT (0.5 mmol, 0.094 g), CoCl2·6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.12 g,) and TPBTC (0.23 mmol, 0.100 g,) was dissolved in the mixed solution of DMA–H2O–HBF4 (21 mL, 10:3:1, v/v/v) and then heated in 120 °C oven for 1 day. After cooling to room temperature, the orange bulk-shaped single crystals were obtained (yield: 55%, based on HCPT). Elemental analysis calculated (found) for [Co3(μ3-OH)­(CPT)3(H2O)3]­Cl2(DMA)6(H2O)6 (C51H91Co3N15Cl2O22): C, 40.46 (41.48); H, 6.06 (5.81); N, 13.88 (14.56). FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3417 (s), 3097 (s), 2939 (w), 1683 (w), 1606 (s), 1512 (s), 1398 (s), 1333 (m), 1297 (m), 1240 (m), 1089 (m), 1016 (m), 839 (m), 784 (s), 711 (w), 592 (m), 534 (m) cm–1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of [Co3(μ3-OH)(CPT)3(H2O)3]Cl2(DMA)5.5(H2O)5 (FJU-88)

A mixture of HCPT (0.5 mmol, 0.094 g) and CoCl2⋅6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.120 g) was dissolved in the mixed solution of N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA)-H2O-HBF4 (21 mL, 10:3:1, v/v/v, DMA = N,N'-dimethylacetamide) and then heated in 120 °C oven for 1 day. After cooling to room temperature, the light orange rod-shaped single crystals were obtained (yield: 65%, based on HCPT). Elemental analysis calculated (found) for [Co3(μ3-OH)(CPT)3(H2O)3]Cl2(DMA)5.5(H2O)5 (C49H84.5Co3N14.5Cl2O20.5): C, 40.52 (41.84); H, 5.86 (5.71); N, 13.98 (13.65). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) (KBr, cm-1): 3417 (s), 3133 (s), 2924 (m), 1608 (s), 1541 (s), 1402 (s), 1246 (s), 1180 (w), 1093 (s), 864 (m), 785 (s), 696 (m), 624 (m), 517 (s) cm-1.

Synthesis of [Co3(μ3-OH)(CPT)3(H2O)3]Cl2(DMA)6(H2O)6 (FJU-89)

A mixture of HCPT (0.5 mmol, 0.094 g), CoCl2⋅6H2O (0.5 mmol, 0.12 g,) and TPBTC (0.23 mmol, 0.100 g,) was dissolved in the mixed solution of DMA-H2O-HBF4 (21 mL, 10:3:1, v/v/v) and then heated in 120 °C oven for 1 day. After cooling to room temperature, the orange bulk-shaped single crystals were obtained (yield: 55%, based on HCPT). Elemental analysis calculated (found) for [Co3(μ3-OH)(CPT)3(H2O)3]Cl2(DMA)6(H2O)6 (C51H91Co3N15Cl2O22): C, 40.46 (41.48); H, 6.06 (5.81); N, 13.88 (14.56). FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3417 (s), 3097 (s), 2939 (w), 1683 (w), 1606 (s), 1512 (s), 1398 (s), 1333 (m), 1297 (m), 1240 (m), 1089 (m), 1016 (m), 839 (m), 784 (s), 711 (w), 592 (m), 534 (m) cm-1.

cln_elements.content:
For permanent porosity establishment, the freshly as-synthesized sample was soaked in anhydrous CH3OH to exchange the guest solvents, and then pumped under high vacuum at 333 K overnight to get guest-free phases FJU-88a and FJU-89a. As shown in Figure S10, the 77 K N2 adsorption of FJU-88a is much less and with no pore volume, which may be caused by the removal of solvent from pores and the collapse of porous structures, as the further PXRD patterns confirm (Figure S6). In contrast, the activated FJU-89a showed two types of combined isotherms: type I, a steep rise in the low-pressure range, and type IV, obvious adsorption–desorption hysteresis in the relative pressure range of 0.5–0.9 (a). Such combined adsorption behavior has also been observed in other hierarchically porous MOFs. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller and Langmuir surface area calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherms are 774 and 1202 m2/g, respectively (Figure S11). The total pore volume obtained from the maximum N2 uptake is 0.68 cm3/g (including 0.32 cm3/g of micropore volume), slightly lower than the theoretical value of 1.16 cm3/g. The difference between theoretical and experimental results is mainly due to the shrinkage of the activated host framework, which was further confirmed by the PXRD patterns (Figure S7). The pore-size distribution (PSD) of FJU-89a was calculated using the no-local density functional theory (NLDFT) model, showing the coexistence of micropores and mesopores as the major pores located in the range of 0.5–1.1 and 8–12 nm, respectively (b).

Gas Adsorption

Establishment of permanent porosity and optimized pore space within the framework of FJU-89a encourages us to study its adsorption and separation performances. At 273 K and 1 bar, the uptake capacities of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 are 123.3, 94.2, and 22.5 cm3/g, respectively (c). Similarly, the uptake value of C2H2 is 101.4 cm3/g, which is higher than the values of CO2 (61.1 cm3/g) and CH4 (14.0 cm3/g), at 296 K and 1 bar (d). Although the uptake capacity of C2H2 in FJU-89a at 296 K is lower than some famous MOFs with high density of open-metal sites, for example, FJI-H8 (224 cm3/g) and HKUST-1 (201 cm3/g), the adsorbed C2H2 is comparable to FJU-22a (114.8 cm3/g) and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (91.8 cm3/g) and much higher than ZJU-196a (83.5 cm3/g), UTSA-300a (68.9 cm3/g), and NKMOF-1-Ni (61.0 cm3/g). The zero surface coverage isosteric heat of adsorptions (Q st) of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 for FJU-89a, derived from the 273 K and 296 K adsorption isotherms and fitted using the virial equation, are 31.0, 27.8, and 18.1 kJ/mol, respectively (Figure S12). Obviously, the interaction between C2H2 and host skeleton is stronger than that of CO2 and CH4.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Pore Textural Properties

For permanent porosity establishment, the freshly as-synthesized sample was soaked in anhydrous CH3OH to exchange the guest solvents, and then pumped under high vacuum at 333 K overnight to get guest-free phases FJU-88a and FJU-89a. As shown in Figure S10, the 77 K N2 adsorption of FJU-88a is much less and with no pore volume, which may be caused by the removal of solvent from pores and the collapse of porous structures, as the further PXRD patterns confirm (Figure S6). In contrast, the activated FJU-89a showed two types of combined isotherms: type I, a steep rise in the low-pressure range, and type IV, obvious adsorption-desorption hysteresis in the relative pressure range of 0.5-0.9 (a). Such combined adsorption behavior has also been observed in other hierarchically porous MOFs. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller and Langmuir surface area calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherms are 774 and 1202 m2/g, respectively (Figure S11). The total pore volume obtained from the maximum N2 uptake is 0.68 cm3/g (including 0.32 cm3/g of micropore volume), slightly lower than the theoretical value of 1.16 cm3/g. The difference between theoretical and experimental results is mainly due to the shrinkage of the activated host framework, which was further confirmed by the PXRD patterns (Figure S7). The pore-size distribution (PSD) of FJU-89a was calculated using the no-local density functional theory (NLDFT) model, showing the coexistence of micropores and mesopores as the major pores located in the range of 0.5-1.1 and 8-12 nm, respectively (b).

Gas Adsorption

Establishment of permanent porosity and optimized pore space within the framework of FJU-89a encourages us to study its adsorption and separation performances. At 273 K and 1 bar, the uptake capacities of C2H2, CO2, and CH4 are 123.3, 94.2, and 22.5 cm3/g, respectively (c). Similarly, the uptake value of C2H2 is 101.4 cm3/g, which is higher than the values of CO2 (61.1 cm3/g) and CH4 (14.0 cm3/g), at 296 K and 1 bar (d). Although the uptake capacity of C2H2 in FJU-89a at 296 K is lower than some famous MOFs with high density of open-metal sites, for example, FJI-H8 (224 cm3/g) and HKUST-1 (201 cm3/g), the adsorbed C2H2 is comparable to FJU-22a (114.8 cm3/g) and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (91.8 cm3/g) and much higher than ZJU-196a (83.5 cm3/g), UTSA-300a (68.9 cm3/g), and NKMOF-1-Ni (61.0 cm3/g). Obviously, the interaction between C2H2 and host skeleton is stronger than that of CO2 and CH4.

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Representation of the Syntheses of a Pair of Conformational Isomers (FJU-88 and FJU-89)

cln_elements.content: Trinuclear Co­(II) unit and organic ligand HCPT in FJU-88 (a) and FJU-89 (f) and viewed as six connected nodes and two connected linkers, respectively. The coordination mode and the twist angle between the plane of triazole ring and benzene ring of the CPT in FJU-88 (b) and FJU-89 (g). The trigonal bipyramidal cage Co15(CPT)6 and the twisted octahedral cage Co18(CPT)8 were observed in FJU-88 (c) and FJU-89 (h). (d) The 3D framework of FJU-88 showing hexagonal 1D channel view along the c axis, (i) the 3D framework of FJU-89 showing two types of 1D channels view along the a axis. Schematic views of the acs and snw topological structures in FJU-88 (e) and FJU-89 (j). Color code: Co, orange or light purple; O, red; N, blue; C, dark gray. Guest molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.

(d) The 3D framework of FJU-88 showing hexagonal 1D channel view along the c axis, (i) the 3D framework of FJU-89 showing two types of 1D channels view along the a axis. metadata.title:
Additive-Induced
Supramolecular Isomerism and Enhancement
of Robustness in Co(II)-Based MOFs for Efficiently Trapping Acetylene
from Acetylene-Containing Mixtures
